facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 243 of 1971 is an appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated September 3, 1970 of the Madhya Pradesh High Court in Miscellaneous Petition No. 256 of 1970.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 243 of 1971. Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated September 3, 1970 of the Madhya Pradesh High Court in Miscella

facts.text: Appellant filed a writ petition against the order of the Chancellor of Saugar University dated 15th June 1970 cancelling his appointment as Vice-Chancellor.

anchor.surface_text: This is an appeal by special leave against the summary dismissal, of a Writ Petition filed by the appellant against the order of the Chancellor of the Saugar University dated the 15th Ju

facts.text: Appointment of Vice-Chancellor of Saugar University is made by the Chancellor from a panel of not less than three persons recommended by a Committee constituted under section 13(2) of the University of Saugar Act, 1946.

anchor.surface_text: It may at the outset be mentioned that the appointment of the Vice-Chancollor of the Saugar University is made by the Chancellor of that University under section 13 of the University of S

facts.text: Committee consisted of G. K. Shinde (Retired Chief Justice, elected by Executive Council, Chairman), Justice T. P. Naik (MP High Court, elected), Shri C. B. Agarwal (Retired Judge Allahabad High Court, nominated by Chancellor Rajmata Vijaya Raje Scindia).

anchor.surface_text: It appears that under the above provisions a Committee to submit a panel of names for the appointment of a Vice-Chancellor for the University was duly companystituted companysisting of two

facts.text: Committee meeting fixed at Indore on 4th April 1970.

anchor.surface_text: The Chairman thereafter appears to have carried on a companyrespondence to fix, a companyvenient place and time for the meeting, which was ultimately fixed at Indore on the 4th of April

facts.text: Justice Naik unable to attend the meeting on 4th April 1970.

anchor.surface_text: Justice Naik was, however, unable to attend the meeting and in, his absence the other two persons, Shri Shinde panel of and Shri Agrawal met as a Committee

facts.text: Two members (Shinde and Agrawal) met and submitted panel of names.

anchor.surface_text: and in, his absence the other two persons, Shri Shinde panel of and Shri Agrawal met as a Committee and submitteds names from which the Chancellor appointed the appellant

facts.text: Chancellor appointed appellant Ishwar Chandra as Vice-Chancellor on 7th April 1970 with effect from 22nd June 1970 for five years.

anchor.surface_text: from which the Chancellor appointed the appellant on 7th April 1970 as a vice Chancellor with effect from 22nd June 1970 for, a period of five years.

facts.text: Appellant was acting as Vice-Chancellor at the time of appointment.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant at the time of the appointment, it seems, was acting as Vice- Chancellor. 1061SupCI/72

facts.text: Governor of Madhya Pradesh promulgated Ordinance No. I of 1970 on 9th April 1970 making Governor ex officio Chancellor; previous Chancellor ceased office.

anchor.surface_text: On the 9th of April 1970, the Governor of Madhya Pradesh, Shri K. C., Reddy promulgated Ordinance No. I of 1970 by section 2 of which sub-section  1  of section II was substituted

facts.text: Governor promulgated another Ordinance on 23rd April 1970 substituting section 43 and adding 43A retrospectively.

anchor.surface_text: On- the 23rd April 1970, the Governor again passed another Ordinance by section 2 of which, he substituted section 43 of the Act by a new section

facts.text: Secretary to Governor wrote to appellant on 20th May 1970 questioning legality of committee meeting with two members and seeking reply within a week.

anchor.surface_text: After the above Ordinances were promulgated, the Secretary to the Governor of Madhya Pradesh wrote on the 20th May 1970 to the appellant as follows - The question has companye up

facts.text: Appellant replied to show cause notice on 9th June 1970 after obtaining extension of time.

anchor.surface_text: To this letter the appellant sent a reply on the 9th June 1970 after having earlier obitained an extension of time.

facts.text: Chancellor cancelled appellant's appointment order dated 7th April 1970 on 15th June 1970 under section 43A.

facts.text: Writ petition filed in Madhya Pradesh High Court on 1st July 1970.

anchor.surface_text: On the 1st July 1970, a Writ Petition was filed in the High Court of Madhya Pradesh

facts.text: High Court directed production of correspondence on 3rd July 1970.

anchor.surface_text: and it appears that on the 3rd July 1970 the Court directed the appellant to produce the companyrespondence between the Chairman, and the members of the Selection Committee

facts.text: Appellant produced correspondence with affidavit on 25th July 1970.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant, if seems, produced the companyrespondence with an affidavit on the 25th July 1970 stating that he had obtained the companyrespondence

facts.text: High Court refused rule nisi on 3rd September 1970.

anchor.surface_text: On the 3rd of September 1970 rule nisi was refused.

facts.text: High Court rejected application for leave to appeal to Supreme Court on 19th September 1970.

anchor.surface_text: On the 19th September 1970 die application for leave to appeal to the Supreme, Court was also rejected.

facts.text: Chancellor's order held appellant's appointment invalid because only two members present at meeting.

anchor.surface_text: It is clear from the Governors impugned order that the appellants appointment was held to be invalid because only two members of the Committee were present at the meeting.

facts.text: High Court presumed Chancellor's consideration was not merely quorum but validity of meeting call, based on correspondence.

facts.text: Chairman wrote to Justice Naik on 12th February 1970 inquiring about 7th and 8th March at Bhopal.

anchor.surface_text: The companyrespondence shows that the Chairman had written a letter on the 12th February 1970 in which , he inquired of Justice Naik whether the 7th and 8th March 1970 would suit him

facts.text: Chairman wrote on 20th February 1970 postponing meeting as other member abroad.

anchor.surface_text: Later on the 20th February 1970, he wrote another letter saying that the other member was abroad, and therefore, the meeting which was proposed

facts.text: Justice Naik replied on 27th February 1970 asking for new date.

anchor.surface_text: In fact, Justice Naik replied on the 27th February 1970 acknow- ledging these letters and asking him to let him know the date

facts.text: Chairman fixed meeting on 12th March 1970 at Indore on 8th March 1970 letter.

anchor.surface_text: On the 8th March 1970 Mr. Shinde again wrote to Justice Naik fixing the meeting on the 12th March 1970 at 10.30 a.m. at Indore

facts.text: Shinde telegram on 16th March 1970 asking if 4th April suitable at Indore.

anchor.surface_text: On the 16th March 1970 Shinde sent a telegram to Justice Naik asking him to wire if 4th April was suitable at Indore.

facts.text: Supreme Court held that meeting of two out of three members was valid as no quorum specified and majority present with sufficient notice.

issues.text: Whether the meeting of the committee constituted under section 13(2) of the Act held on 4th April 1970 at Indore at which only two members out of the three were present was legal, and whether the recommendations made by the committee at that meeting were legally valid?

anchor.surface_text: The question has come up before the Chancellor whether the meeting of the committee constituted by his predecessor under section 13 (2 ) of the Act held on 4th April 1970 at Indore at which only two members out of the three were present was legal, and whether the recommendations made by the committee at that meeting were legally valid.

issues.text: Whether the appointment order dated the 7th April 1970 was not in accordance with provisions of section 13 of the University of Saugar Act, 1946, justifying cancellation under section 43A?

anchor.surface_text: The Governor did not, however, accept the appellants plea but passed the following impugned orders on the 15th June 1970 - WHEREAS, on applications made in that behalf, the Chancellor is of the opinion that order dated the 7th April 1970, passed by his predecessor in office appointing Shri Ishwar Chandra as Vice-Chancellor of the University of Saugar with effect from the 22nd June 1970, for a period of five years is not in accordance with provisions of section 13 of the University of Saugar Act, 1946 ( XVI of 1946 ) hereinafter referred to as the said Act NOW, THEREFORE, in exercise of the powers conferred by section 43A of the said Act,

issues.text: Whether there was prima facie material based on the correspondence for the Chancellor's opinion under section 43A that the meeting was not legal due to deliberate exclusion of a member?

anchor.surface_text: The assumption in this order rejecting the Writ Petition is not warranted, firstly, because the correspondence does not show that there was any deliberate attempt made by the Chairman to exclude one of the members in this case, Justice P. Naik, and secondly, that the Chancellor had because of this exclusion, declared the meeting held on the 4th April 1970 as not being valid. We have- already pointed out that the Chancellor was merely concerned with the legality of the recommendation made by two out of three members and not that,any attempt was made by the Chairman, to, exclude one of the members,

issues.text: Whether in the absence of any rule, regulation or provision fixing quorum for the committee meeting, the presence of a majority of members constitutes a valid meeting?

arguments.claim: The meeting of the committee held on 4th April 1970 was illegal and the recommendations invalid because only two members out of three were present

anchor.surface_text: The question has come up before the Chancellor whether the meeting of the committee constituted by his predecessor under section 13 (2 ) of the Act held on 4th April 1970 at Indore at which only two members out of the three were present was legal, and whether the recommendations made by the committee at that meeting were legally valid.

arguments.court_reasoning: No provision fixing quorum; majority (2/3) with sufficient notice constitutes valid meeting per common law principle (Halsbury)

arguments.claim: Chancellor concerned only with legality of recommendation by two out of three, not deliberate exclusion

anchor.surface_text: We have already pointed out that the Chancellor was merely concerned with the legality of the recommendation made by two out of three members and not that any attempt was made by the Chairman to exclude one of the members

arguments.claim: High Court examined correspondence to sustain Chancellor's order on grounds other than those relied by Chancellor, which was not justified

anchor.surface_text: The High Court delved into the correspondence to sustain the order of the Chancellor on grounds other than those relied upon by him in that order for dismissing the Writ Petition in limine, which in our view, was not justified.

holdings.text: In the absence of any rule, regulation or provision fixing the quorum, the presence of the majority of the members constitutes a valid meeting and decisions taken therein are valid.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Applies well-recognised common law principle that majority constitutes quorum when no specific provision exists, supported by Halsbury's Laws of England.

holdings.text: The meeting of the committee on 4th April 1970 with two out of three members present was legal as sufficient notice was given to all members and no quorum was specified.

anchor.surface_text: It is also not denied that the meeting held by two of the three members on the 4th April 1970 was legal because sufficient notice was given to all the three members. If for one reason or the other one of them could not attend, that does not make the meeting of others illegal.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Correspondence shows repeated attempts to fix meeting with notice to absent member; majority present suffices under common law.

holdings.text: The Chancellor's impugned order cancelling the appointment was invalid as the appointment was made in accordance with section 13 from a valid panel.

anchor.surface_text: There is little doubt that the impugned Order made by the Chancellor was based entirely on the legality of the meeting where only two out of three members were present when the name of the appellant was recommended.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Committee meeting valid per h1 and h2; thus basis for s43A review (non-conformity with s13) absent.

holdings.text: There was no prima facie material for the Chancellor's opinion under section 43A as the correspondence showed no deliberate exclusion of Justice Naik and Chancellor did not peruse it.

anchor.surface_text: The assumption in this order rejecting the Writ Petition is not warranted, firstly, because the correspondence does not show that there was any deliberate attempt made by the Chairman to exclude one of the members in this case, Justice P. Naik... There is also nothing in the materials on the record to show that the correspondence cited above was persued by the Chancellor

holdings.reasoning_summary: Review of correspondence reveals no intent to exclude; no evidence Chancellor considered it before forming opinion or order.

holdings.text: The High Court was not justified in delving into the correspondence to sustain the Chancellor's order on grounds of deliberate exclusion not relied upon by the Chancellor.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court delved into the correspondence to sustain the order of the Chancellor on grounds other than those relied upon by him in that order for dismissing the Writ Petition in limine, which in our view, was not justified.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Chancellor concerned only with number present (quorum); High Court improperly introduced new ground without basis in Chancellor's reasoning or materials.
